Award.AwardTitle: NSF/DMR-BSF: Origin of Large Electromechanical Response in Non-Classical Electrostrictors
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Materials with strong mechanical response to applied electric field are of great importance for a wide range of applications ranging from actuators for portable cameras to transducers for audio-speakers and sonars. Since discovery of a giant electromechanical response in gadolinium-doped cerium oxides in 2012, this material is considered as a new type of ceramic that generates strain due to a small fraction of their structural units, called electromechanically "active". The main challenge towards understanding this mechanism and rational designing new electromechanical materials with the desired response has been the inability to decipher atomic architecture of these units and "catch them in action", that is, to take a snapshot of these units while the strain is generated under electric field. In order to fully characterize the structure of active units "in action", the investigators are studying thin film doped cerium oxide ceramics under electric field by high energy resolution methods (such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy) and modeling the results by advanced theoretical methods. The project impacts the field of ceramic materials through the development of fundamental understanding and design criteria for this new class of electromechanical materials. The project fosters international ties between Yeshiva University in New York and Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot, Israel. The broader impacts of this project are realized through establishing connections between faculty and students from both institutions, and in engaging underrepresented groups (such as women) in science and engineering disciplines.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Thin films of cerium oxide that have trivalent metal impurities possess intriguing structural, electric and mechanical properties, including ionic conductivity, non-linear elastic effects and strong mechanical stresses in response to the application of electric field. Anatoly Frenkel (SUNY at Stony Brook), his international collaborator Igor Lubomirsky (Weizmann Institute of Science) and their respective groups are working to understand the mechanisms of electrostriction (a particularly large electromechanical response that is quadratic with electric field). The investigators strive to answer such fundamental questions as the effects of impurities on the generation of strain and stress in the lattice. They are applying advanced methods of X-ray absorption spectroscopy with high energy resolution in situ, under applied field, to identify the active species - cations that are located in the distorted units - in order to understand, in detail, the behavior of these units and their role in the electrostriction. Data analysis is being carried out by modeling structural distortions theoretically and comparing their simulated X-ray absorption spectra with experimental ones. This project offers research opportunities and training at advanced national research facilities at the post-graduate, graduate and undergraduate levels with significant inclusion of underrepresented female students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific focus of this project was to develop fundamental understanding of structure and properties of a new type of ceramic materials that exhibit very large electromechanical response and are Si-CMOS compatible and non-toxic. The model systems that were used were recently discovered ceramics such as Gd-doped ceria. These materials combine very large electrostriction coefficient and relatively low dielectric constant, indicating that a previously unknown type of electromechanical response is at work. The preliminary studies of the PI, Prof. Anatoly Frenkel, and International Collaborator, Prof. Igor Lubomirsky, performed by differential in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) indicated that, in contrast to ?classical? piezoelectrics and electrostrictors, in Gd-doped ceria generation of strain is due to a minority of local elastic dipoles that respond dynamically to electric field. In order to uncover the nature of these elastic dipoles, characterize their structure, dynamics and their relationship to the electromechanical response, they studied these new materials under electric field in situ by modulation excitation XAS methods, aided by theoretical modeling, such as Reverse Monte Carlo simulations of positions of different components (Ce, O, Gd and vacancies) in the lattice. They developed and synthesize a series of experimental model systems for this study in order to identify main descriptors of their electromechanical response. Those model systems include thin films and bulk ceria doped with various trivalent ions, predominantly rare earths.

This work provided new chemical and physical data for theoretical understanding.  This project offered research opportunities at both the post-graduate and graduate levels.

   The intellectual merits

Combination of advanced synchrotron characterization based on modulation excitation spectroscopy, combined with ab initio XAS theory and Reverse Monte Carlo simulations, helped resolve three-dimensional positions of local environment around each metal species and to link the local structural effects and experimentally measured strain. The combination of experiment and theory helped explain the mechanism of electromechanical response in new type of ceramic materials. In summary, the project has three important outcomes. First, it is the development of a general method for in situ detection of dynamic response of electromechanically active species in ceramic materials due to electric field. Second, it is the discovery of key descriptors of electromechanical response and principles of design of materials with the desired response. Third, it is enabling the development of a fundamentally new class of ceria-based electrostrictive materials.

The broader impacts

There are significant scientific, technological and societal broader impacts of this study. The project will have impacts on the field of ceramic materials due to the development of fundamental understanding and design criteria for the new class of ceria-based electrostrictive materials. The project fostered international ties between Stony Brook University and Weizmann Institute of Science. Faculty and students from the both institutions established connections for scientific collaborations and training future generation of researchers (students and postdocs). This project supported the research efforts of postdocs and Ph.D. students who received unique training in advanced characterization methods and working in multi-disciplinary, international team.
